title: Op-Eds and Persuasive Essays
description: Writing compelling opinion pieces for public audiences

sections.title: Op-Ed Structure
sections.description: Organizing opinion pieces for maximum impact

structure.example: Last week, my daughter asked me why grown-ups can't agree on basic facts. I didn't have a good answer.
We need to treat media literacy as seriously as we treat mathematics.
Research shows that students trained in media literacy are 50% better at identifying misinformation.
Critics worry this amounts to telling students what to think. But teaching how to evaluate sources isn't ideological—it's essential.
Contact your school board. Ask what they're doing to prepare students for our information environment.

techniques.strong: When my uncle forwarded a viral claim about vaccines, I spent two hours fact-checking. Most people won't do that.

techniques.example: Social media companies have made genuine efforts. They're not enough, but they show the problem is solvable.
This isn't about left versus right. It's about citizens versus the algorithms that manipulate us all.

techniques.strong: We're drowning in information while starving for wisdom.

writingTask.title: Opinion Piece
writingTask.prompt: Write an op-ed (250-300 words) arguing for or against requiring social media platforms to verify users' real identities.
writingTask.sampleResponse:
The Case Against Mandatory Identity Verification

When harassment drove her off social media, my friend didn't want anonymity abolished—she wanted it protected. Her harassers used their real names proudly. Anonymity let her rebuild a presence without them finding her.

Proposals to require real-name verification on social media sound sensible: accountability would reduce abuse, the argument goes. If trolls couldn't hide, they wouldn't troll. But this well-intentioned idea would cause more harm than it prevents.

First, it wouldn't work. The most toxic behavior often comes from people using their real names—and proudly so. Studies of Facebook, which has long required real names, show harassment rates comparable to more anonymous platforms. Bad actors determined to cause harm will create fake IDs or steal others'.

Second, it would endanger vulnerable users. Activists in authoritarian countries use anonymity to organize without persecution. LGBTQ youth in unsupportive families use it to find community safely. Domestic violence survivors use it to rebuild lives away from abusers. Mandatory verification hands these users to those who would harm them.

Third, it conflates anonymity with the absence of accountability. Platforms can—and do—enforce community standards without knowing users' legal names. Account suspensions, content removal, and IP bans address behavior without requiring government ID.

The real solution isn't eliminating anonymity but investing in better moderation, clearer standards, and tools that give users more control over their experiences. These approaches address abuse without sacrificing the legitimate benefits of pseudonymity.

Before we dismantle online anonymity in the name of safety, we should ask: whose safety, and at whose expense? For many users, anonymity isn't the problem—it's the protection.
